message: https://convore.com/django-community/open-source-django-cms-for-newspaper/
Related to our discussion of django-cms vs. plain django vs. plain static markup/styles:
https://convore.com/django-community/open-source-django-cms-for-newspaper/
Related to our discussion of django-cms vs. plain django vs. plain static markup/styles:
https://convore.com/django-community/open-source-django-cms-for-newspaper/
A guy posts on that list: It looks like a newspaper website like washingtonpost, it include news, videos, audio news, and classifieds.. and Ads system... i think Django-CMS isn't enough for this..
I've used django-cms with great success for almost that exact website
I really do think we'd be good with just django and django templates for now
django-cms can come later if needed
using app-hooks, if django can do it, django-cms can deliver it
or rather, interface with it
I'd really be hesitant to do static html
Just that we've been discussing it lately
Yeah, I should have been more clear. I don't mean we need those things discussed, just interesting to see CMS alternatives discussed in a context like that.
i agree
and this is weird, but my responses to the google group didn't seem to get posted yesterday

but i wanted to make say that i wasn't trying to start any kind of tech war, ive just missed out on some convos, and was making sure we're using the right tools for the right job (not sure what that job totally entails)
but django for just a static site (though a little overkill) is simple enuff that i think its totally cool
and then later we can add whatever whenever we need/want it
@sambao21 Not sure what happened there. I checked the settings on the google group and you're allowed to post without moderation, so hopefully that won't happen again.
Not sure this is the place to post or to start a new conversation? Jeff suggested we use Gondor to host pythonkc.com (http://gondor.io)  I got a beta invite and it looks pretty sweet, and free!
I am a big fan of rackspace cloud, but that's only because it's the only ssh no restriction ubuntu host I have ever used.
Gondor looks pretty nice. How difficult is it with django to migrate from one host to another?

I'm playing with dotcloud right now, which seems very similar and just came out of beta. If the pricing structure is anywhere similar for gondor, we'll want to be inquiring about a free non-commercial account sooner than later.

I'm playing with dotcloud right now, which seems very similar and just came out of beta. If the pricing structure is anywhere similar for gondor, we'll want to be inquiring about a free non-commercial account sooner than later.

I've been playing with ep.io as well and it's pretty solid. If you want to save money, I'd suggest going with gondor or ep.io (or dotcloud but I've not played with it). Jacob through up http://dddash.ep.io/ in a few hours on ep.io which impressed me.

I really like the format that Oxford Geeks Nights (http://oxford.geeknights.net/) have been using (since 2007). Each meeting is essentially the home page and it highlights the upcoming meeting. Each page then serves as notes for the previous meeting (see http://oxford.geeknights.net/2011/apr-13th/). It’s an interesting format and I thought I’d throw it out there for one more idea for you.
Really like the oxford geek nights website.  I wouldn't feel bad ripping it off wholesale - very cool

Their format for meetings is interesting as well.  2 15 minute keynotes and 4 5 minute lightening talks.  Seems like that would be a good way to get every one involved with some pretty minimal effort.
I'm a +1 for using gondor or ep.io as well.  Whichever ends up making the most sense.  Do we have invites for both?
@blueteal not sure how _easy_ it would be to export a site from gondor, but it doesn't seem like it would be that tricky... I'm probably not the right person to answer that though.
@andrewschoen I got an invite for gondor, but that's for me personally. Might be a good idea to get signed up as pythonkc using the gmail account.
Interesting read - http://kencochrane.net/blog/2011/06/django-hosting-roundup-who-wins/
@juliaelman  Ok. My thought was, if migration is easy, we don't have to feel locked to a particular service. If it is difficult, a bit more care making a decision might help.
@jefftriplett very interesting article. Thanks.
Back over here, so I can quit cluttering up the design thread :)
Fire away with the feedback. Trying to keep it minimal and not fully replace Meetup.com's API client.
Here is a minimal Meetup.com API client: https://github.com/estebistec/pythonkc-meetups
@estebistec looks good.  only thing I see missing is getting a list of the attendees of past meetups.
Also, if we want this in the pythonkc github account just create a repo there for me to push to, manage, etc.
I'll get that in soon
I'll get that in soon
I'll get that in soon
Attendees added: https://github.com/estebistec/pythonkc-meetups/commit/ddb23bb7ce575d7483a82c8fb9ca6a9d6df4c2cb

@estebistec  we do need to figure out how to get around the limiter on the api.  I was thinking past events would definitely be stored in a db for the site.  we'd want to add stuff like video links, slideshare links, etc. to it
@estebistec just set up a pythonkc github account and added you to the project.  I just forked pythonkc-meetups from your account

On the topic of caching: I didn't know of the cache template tag, so I think that'll honestly do us nicely for our purposes: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/cache/?from=olddocs#template-fragment-caching
thanks to jeff for that suggestion
